metadata.case_name: State of West Bengal v. K. Mondal & Sons

facts.text: On February 8, 1944, respondent offered to put up temporary storage godowns at Arambagh for Civil Supplies Department of Bengal; accepted by letter dated February 12, 1944; construction completed; bill for Rs. 39,476/- paid in July 1944.
On April 7, 1944, Sub-Divisional Officer, Arambagh requested respondent to submit estimate for construction of kutcha road, guard room, office, kitchen and room for clerks at Arambagh.
Additional Deputy Director of Civil Supplies visited Arambagh on April 20, 1944, and instructed respondent to proceed with construction per estimates.
Respondent completed constructions; bill for Rs. 2,322/8 submitted to Assistant Director on April 27, 1944.
Sub-Divisional Officer required construction of storage sheds at Khanakul; Assistant Director wrote on April 18, 1944, asking respondent to proceed.
Respondent completed storage sheds at Khanakul; bill for Rs. 17,003/- submitted.
Bills for Rs. 2,322/8 and Rs. 17,003/- remained unpaid; total claim Rs. 19,325/- in suit filed by respondent against State of West Bengal.
Appellant denied material allegations; alleged requests invalid and unauthorised under s.175(3) GOI Act 1935; no privity of contract.

Trial court (G.K. Mitter J.) held no valid contract under s.175(3); s.65 inapplicable; but claim valid under s.70 Contract Act; not barred by limitation; liability devolved under Indian Independence (Rights, Property and Liabilities) Order 1947; decree for respondent.
Calcutta High Court (S.R. Das Gupta and Bachawat JJ.) confirmed trial court findings; appeal dismissed.
Respondent aware officers lacked authority to bind government; awaited sanction; work done despite no formal contract.
Government accepted and used the constructions; no contest to quantum or benefit enjoyed.

legal_issues.text: Whether s.70 of Indian Contract Act applies to claim for compensation where works done for government without valid contract under s.175(3) of Government of India Act 1935, and government enjoyed benefit.
Whether contracts invalid for non-compliance with s.175(3) GOI Act 1935.
Whether liability devolved on State of West Bengal under Indian Independence Order 1947.

petitioner_arguments.text: No valid contract under s.175(3) GOI Act 1935 as not executed by authorised persons; s.70 inapplicable as it would circumvent mandatory provisions; based on English cases like H. Young & Co. v. Mayor of Leamington Spa; work not 'lawfully done'; analogy to minor's incapacity.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.175(3) GOI Act 1935; s.70, s.23 Contract Act; H. Young & Co. v. Mayor of Leamington Spa

petitioner_arguments.text: Trial and High Court erred in applying s.70; contracts invalid, no privity; limitation barred; no devolution of liability.

respondent_arguments.text: Works done per requests; if no valid contract, claim under s.70 as lawfully done non-gratuitously and enjoyed benefit; previously paid for similar work.

court_reasoning.text: Contracts invalid under mandatory s.175(3) GOI Act 1935; non-compliance makes void; object to protect state from unauthorised claims.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Failure to comply with s.175(3) nullifies contract.

court_reasoning.text: s.70 applies: (1) lawfully done (not forbidden by law; independent of invalid contract); (2) not gratuitously; (3) enjoyed benefit voluntarily; no circumvention of s.175(3) as separate fields; supplements it for petty/emergency works.
court_reasoning.key_observation: s.70 prevents unjust enrichment; lawful relation arises from acceptance.

court_reasoning.text: No tacit personal contract with officers; work for government; all s.70 conditions satisfied; English cases irrelevant for statutory construction.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Work done without any contract; government accepted benefit.

court_reasoning.text: Distinguished Chatturbhuj case; followed Bhikraj Jaipuria; no analogy to minor.
court_reasoning.key_observation: State subject to s.70 like individuals.

holdings.text: Contracts invalid under s.175(3) GOI Act 1935.
s.70 Contract Act applicable; respondent entitled to compensation as conditions satisfied.
Liability devolved on State of West Bengal.

precedents_cited.case_name: Seth Bhikraj Jaipuria v. Union of India
Chatturbhuj Vithaldas Jasani v. Moreshwar Parashram
precedents_cited.relevance: Contract non-enforceable but not void for s.7(d) RP Act purposes; capable of ratification.

precedents_cited.case_name: H. Young & Co. v. Mayor and Corporation of Royal Leamington Spa
precedents_cited.relevance: Statutory seal requirement mandatory; no liability despite benefit.

precedents_cited.case_name: Lawford v. Billericay Rural District Council
precedents_cited.relevance: Implied contract where common law seal requirement.

precedents_cited.case_name: Union of India v. Ramnagina Singh
precedents_cited.relevance: s.70 inapplicable to void agreement request.

precedents_cited.case_name: Mathura Mohan Saha v. Ram Kumar Saha
precedents_cited.relevance: s.70 applies to invalid government contracts.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Contract Act, 1872
statutes_cited.relevance: s.70 for compensation where no contract but benefit enjoyed; s.65 inapplicable.

statutes_cited.name: Government of India Act, 1935
statutes_cited.relevance: Mandatory for government contracts; non-compliance voids contract.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Independence (Rights, Property and Liabilities) Order, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Liability devolved to State of West Bengal.

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed; decree of High Court upheld awarding Rs.19,325/- to respondent under s.70 Contract Act as works lawfully done non-gratuitously and benefit enjoyed by State despite no valid contract under s.175(3) GOI Act.

key_quotes.text: "The word 'shall' used in s.175(3) is intended to make the provision obligatory and not directory."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "s.70 prevents unjust enrichment and it applies as much to individuals as to corporations and Government."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "There was no agreement either express or implied between the plaintiff and the Province of Bengal."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: No contract existed; s.70 directly applies.
